options: I wonder if we should consider changing our policy on performance appraisals? What do you think?
Sean, your approach to appraisal is completely off track and does not reflect available evidence.
The system that has been developed needs to be implemented. We have already spent enough time in discussion.
Forget about the change in this policy. It is fine as it is.
questions.rationale: Males and females in the workplace are likely to have different management styles, and although not all males are authoritative or females more participatory, women are likely to use more participatory and inclusive methods.

questions.stem: During the performance appraisal, you praise Xia for her attention to and care for nursing details. You suggest that her care would be further enhanced by a greater acknowledgment of patients‘ feelings. Xia bursts into tears and leaves the office. Later, you learn that criticism is perceived as akin to failure in Xia‘s culture. You reflect on how you could modify your approach in the future to acknowledge different cultural interpretations of feedback. Your response is indicative of:
questions.rationale: Cultural awareness involves self-examination and in-depth exploration of one‘s own cultural and professional background, including biases, prejudices, and assumptions, including assumptions about thinking modes and decision making.

questions.stem: In caring for a patient from an East Indian culture, the staff expresses frustration that many people are in the room at any one time, which interferes with care. As the nurse manager, you provide leadership in understanding that this behavior of the family and friend network reflects:
options: lack of understanding of the seriousness of the patient‘s illness.
lack of communication between family members.
The social organization of friendships and family networks in East Indian culture.
lack of caring about the hospital environment by the friends and family.
questions.rationale: The Giger and Davidhizar Transcultural Model identifies six phenomena to assess the provision of care for patients who are from different cultures, including social organizations, which include how relationships are formed and expressed in different cultures.

questions.stem: As a new nurse manager, you are aware of leadership, management, and followership principles. What is the first step to becoming an effective leader?
questions.rationale: Being an effective follower is the first step in becoming an effective leader. A leader may take classes on leadership and classes on management, as well as secure and advanced degrees. The first step to effective leadership is effective followership.

questions.stem: As a nurse manager and the leader of the unit, you are aware of multiple avenues for learning leadership traits. Which avenues would you pursue for learning leadership traits? (Select all that apply.)
options: Connecting with other leaders in the organization

questions.stem: As a nurse manager, you are a leader in health care and on the unit you manage. Looking at the larger picture of health care and patient environment on the unit, what is your primary role when evaluating the care provided on your nursing unit?
options: Assess staff for contentment in the unit.
Ensure quality patient care on the unit.
Provide education to the staff of the unit.
questions.rationale: 50 Your primary role as a nurse manager is ensuring quality patient care. You must also focus on cost outcomes, assess your staff frequently, and provide education to the staff. However, as a leader in evaluating the larger picture of health care, quality care is a priority.

questions.stem: A new graduate nurse has accepted a position in an intensive care unit. The nurse is assigned a preceptor with several years of experience. The new nurse also notices that the other staff seek this nurse out for answers to questions and as a resource to the unit. What does the new nurse consider the role of the mentor nurse?
questions.rationale: Formal leaders, positional leaders, and official leaders hold positions of leadership or titles. In this scenario, the nurse is the formal leader of the unit. The nurse is noted to be an informal leader, one who does not hold an actual leadership title, but leads from an informal position based on experience and behavior.

questions.stem: The manager of a nursing unit is having difficulty working with a new graduate nurse. The new graduate nurse is excited and full of ideas she wants to try. The manager decides to journal her feelings regarding the new nurse. What is the nurse manager practicing in this situation?
questions.rationale: Using reflection to evaluate her own feelings, the nurse manager is practicing self-awareness to go beyond the surface and evaluate herself for the determination of personal feelings. This is a higher level of thinking and assists in exploring one‘s individual thoughts and experiences.

questions.stem: A staff nurse is taking leadership classes in an advanced degree program, as the nurse wants to become a manager. The instructor requires the students to create a journal and make notes of their feelings when they experience conflicts at work over the next few weeks. The assignment calls for the use of reflection. What is the purpose of this assignment?
options: Reflection for self-awareness in conflict situations
Assess the students' conflict management skills
questions.rationale: The use of journaling, when done with self-reflection and the use of values to evaluate situations and reflect, assists in self-awareness of situations. In this instance, the instructor wants the students to use self-awareness through the evaluation of conflict occurrences.

questions.stem: The nurse manager is working with a group of new nurses. The new nurses ask questions about leadership and the role of a manager in leading nursing. The manager shares that she has incorporated her core values and beliefs into her role and responsibilities as a nurse manager. What type of leadership has she described?
questions.rationale: The manager has described the use of personal leadership. This incorporates core values and beliefs of the person to improve their role and responsibilities.

questions.stem: A nurse manager, when in a formal leadership position, attempts to translate the picture or vision of her facility across to the staff nurses. The manager is faced with a staff who is resistant to the vision of the facility. What is the theory the manager needs to incorporate to be effective?
questions.rationale: In this instance, the nurse manager needs to utilize the theory of Inspire a Share Vision. This is an expectation of leaders to be able to contribute by translating the big picture vision to the staff.

questions.stem: The manager is using self-reflection to gain insight into improving leadership skills. By using self-awareness, what does a leader develop?
questions.rationale: By using self-awareness, an essential task for leadership, the leader cultivates personal insights and new knowledge of themselves as a leader. Personal growth may or may not occur with self-reflection, improved self-esteem is not guaranteed, and management skills are not obtained.

questions.stem: In developing leadership skills, one should focus on authentic leadership. The theory of authentic leadership focuses on various factors. What is the top priority in the development of authentic leadership?
questions.rationale: The top priority in the development of authentic leadership is the development of honest relationships. Valuing what each person brings to the group, trusting the group, exploring other ideas, accomplishing goals, and being an ineffective organizer are important. However, development and honest relationships is the foundation of authentic leadership.

questions.stem: As a leader in nursing, one must seek new insights and establish personal tools to improve their lifelong learning. Which behavior by a manager would be a concern for a chief nursing executive?
questions.rationale: A chief nursing officer should be concerned if a manager demonstrates complacent behavior. A manager should continually seek to improve leadership skills. All other options are ways to improve personal leadership.

questions.stem: Which of the following is an example of a formal leadership position on a nursing unit?
questions.rationale: The unit manager of a nursing unit is a formal leadership position. A formal leadership position is defined as a role that exerts influence over others and they are in charge.

questions.stem: A new nurse leader wants to be the best leader she can. The nurse takes classes, finds a leadership mentor, seeks input from her unit, and employs other strategies for leadership development. What is another strategy for the leader to develop and improve leadership skills?
questions.rationale: Being an effective leader requires wanting to be proactive in their learning to develop effective leadership skills. Good leaders do not ignore feedback; they take authoritative positions when required, and do not come across as being in charge but rather as being a leader of a group.

questions.stem: The nurse manager frequently interacts with staff and other hospice facility employees. Communication is purposeful because the manager assesses current issues, such as specific satisfactions and dissatisfactions with the newly implemented computerized documentation system. Informally, the manager gathers available staff members to address similar learning needs. Many times, staff members are found coaching other staff about improving the use of the new system. According to Senge (1990), the activities demonstrated in this example are:
questions.rationale: Building a shared vision occurs when leaders involve all members in moving personal visions of the future into a consolidated vision common to members and leaders.

questions.stem: The nurse decides to involve those who will be affected by the change early in the change management process. This can positively result in:
questions.rationale: Successful change means persistence and advancement of the change, which requires the undivided focus of all team members. Early involvement and participation are critical to capturing the undivided focus of team members.

questions.stem: Planning is a process designed to achieve goals in dynamic, competitive environments. As a new manager, what is the first step you will undertake to develop a strategic plan of action for a congestive heart failure program?
options: Search the environment to determine changes that may affect the organization.
Appraise the organization‘s strengths and weaknesses.
Identify the major opportunities for and threats to the organization.
Identify and evaluate the various strategies available to the organization.
questions.rationale: Assessment of the external environment is the first step in the strategic planning process.

questions.stem: As a nursing leadership student, you have had the opportunity to develop a palliative care manual that will be utilized by the palliative care network (PCN) in your region for teaching healthcare professionals. The PCN has requested that you provide a prioritized plan of action for marketing the manual on a regional and state basis. What is the first priority?
options: Communicate benefits to the target group.
questions.rationale: To put a strategic plan into place for marketing, it is necessary to conduct an external assessment.

questions.stem: The chief nursing officer has to write a strategic plan. The most difficult stage in the strategic planning process is:
options: Assessment of the external and internal environment.
Review of mission statement, goals, and objectives.
questions.rationale: Determination of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats requires openness to what is being said and observed and is critical to setting the stage for relevant responses in the latter phases of strategic planning.

questions.stem: The reasons cited by nursing administrators for not planning in a systematic manner include:
options: lack of understanding of the planning process.
lack of knowledge regarding the internal and external operations of the organization.
not enough hours in the day for both day-to-day operations and planning.
delegation of the task to subordinates.
questions.rationale: The nurse manager should participate in strategic planning and quality initiatives with the governing body. Lack of knowledge is a common reason for nonparticipation in planning initiatives.   133

questions.stem: From your observation of planning activities in the organization, you have noticed that planning and decision-making occur at various levels of the organization. The nurse manager has overall responsibility for which of the following?
questions.rationale: The nurse manager should articulate organizational decision-making for the criteria model adopted by the organization and monitor ongoing implementation of the plan.

questions.stem: In assessing the internal environment, the strategic planning team at Pacific Hospital discovers that 90% of staff members have no idea what the current mission statement means. This is most likely related to:
options: The level of abstraction inherent in mission statements.
development of the statement by the administration team with no other staff involvement.
outdated goals and objectives contained in the mission statement.
failure to provide action statements within the mission statement.
questions.rationale: A mission statement reflects the beliefs of the organization in relation to those it serves and the services it provides, and it communicates the direction of an organization. Covey (1990) believes that the process of developing the mission statement is vital to an organization‘s success and should involve everyone.

questions.stem: At the beginning of the strategic planning processes, Pacific Hospital learns that nursing staff members are uncomfortable with utilizing evidence-based practice, and that staff members perceive that only limited resources are available to support translation of evidence into their usual practice. Because this issue has been identified, the management team determines that a plan of action is required to address the issue. Who should be involved at this point?
questions.rationale: The first phase in planning is conducting an assessment of the external and internal environments. Assessment of the internal environment should include all levels of staff and facilitate feedback on the effectiveness of strengths and weaknesses of systems and processes within the institution.

questions.stem: In implementing the strategic plan for effective utilization of evidence to guide nursing practice at Pacific Hospital, the nursing unit managers take the next step, which is the implementation. Implementation most likely would involve:
options: Revisiting the mission statement and objectives.
Re-evaluating external and internal factors affecting evidence-based practice.
Preparing a budget to support implementation.
Developing unit-based objectives related to the plan.
questions.rationale: The previous planning (assessment of internal and external environments, development of a mission and plan, and allocation of resources) has already been completed. The next step involves adapting the strategic plan to the nursing units.

questions.stem: A nurse manager is experiencing conflicts between herself and staff members. She had tried to develop a team by using a shared leadership model to empower the staff. Staff members are functioning:
questions.rationale: A group is a collection of interconnected individuals working together, with a high degree of interdependence, for the same purpose. A team is a unified group that is committed to a common purpose, performance goals, and approach, for which they hold themselves mutually accountable. The conflict indicates that the staff may not be united in a common purpose.

questions.stem: Mobilizing others to accomplish extraordinary things requires what leadership behaviors? (Select all that apply.)
options: Establishing a sense of being in this together
questions.rationale: Leaders who inspire teams to accomplish extraordinary things or to display synergy model the way, inspire shared vision, challenge the status quo, and encourage the heart by celebration of success.

questions.stem: The nurse manager used a mediator to help resolve conflicts on the unit. During the mediation process, the nurse manager saw signs of potential team building. One key concept of an effective team is:
questions.rationale: Team building involves moving toward a common vision, which requires commitment. Conflict and clarification of tasks are components in the development of this commitment.

questions.stem: A mediator suggested that the nurse manager and staff members decide on a method to resolve conflicts. It is important to have agreements about how team members will work together because:
options: If there are no agreements, each member will make up rules about how to handle disagreements and relationships.
People are naturally difficult and will not work well together without such agreements.
People will naturally ask for agreements about how to be together. A way to eliminate nonproductive team members must be available.
questions.rationale: People must agree on the goals and mission with which they are involved. They have to reach some understanding of how they w ill exist together. Tenets or agreements such as ―I will respectfully speak promptly with any team member with whom I have a problem, and I go a long way to avoid gossiping, backbiting, bickering, and misinterpreting others. Without agreement, people have implicit permission to behave in any manner they choose toward one another, including angry, hostile, hurtful, and acting-out behavior.

questions.stem: By following a shared leadership model, the nurse manager believes that staff members will learn to function synergistically. Some teams function synergistically because members:
options: Listen to the person who believes he or she is an expert.
do not speak unless they are absolutely sure they are correct in their views.
questions.rationale: Active listening in a group creates synergy in that team members really hear one another‘s ideas and share in decision-making.

questions.stem: The chief nursing officer decided that the nurse managers need a series of staff-development programs on team building through communication and partnerships. She understood that the nurse managers needed to build confidence in ways of handling various situations. The greatest deterrent to confidence is:
options: lack of clarity in the mission.
lack of control of the environment.
fear that one can‘t handle the consequences.
fear that the boss will not like one‘s work.
questions.rationale: Fear of not being able to manage consequences undermines confidence and a sense of competency.

questions.stem: In the cardiac intensive care unit, there has been simmering discontent about the new nurse manager, who avoids any discussion about her scheduling and practice decisions. The staff have begun to sort into different camps depending on how they feel about the manager or the decisions. Which of the following statements MOST accurately describes this situation?
options: The tension that has been generated will result in creative solutions.
Staff will become a cohesive group that takes a stand against the manager.
The conflict will result in increased dialogue about practice and scheduling options.
Patient care may suffer because attention and energy are being diverted toward the unit relationships.
questions.rationale: Destructive conflict polarizes groups, saps group morale, deepens differences in values, and diverts energy from more important activities, such as patient care. Constructive conflict opens up issues of importance, results in solutions to problems, and enables authentic communication.

questions.stem: The unit manager was addressing nursing students in the lounge area and was discussing team leadership and team effectiveness. She stated, ―One can agree to disagree with another team member‘s perspective even when one doesn‘t necessarily see that perspective as being the correct one. In being creative, what did she mean?
questions.rationale: Caregivers must listen to the other person‘s perspective, listen to the message accurately, identify differences, and creatively seek resolutions.

questions.stem: A nurse manager is discussing with unit staff the repeated lack of staff compliance in documenting exercise activity for post -cardiac surgery clients. The unit‘s licensed practical/vocational nurses are responsible for ensuring that clients carry out the prescribed exercise regimen and that the activity is documented. Using Drucker‘s five basic functions of a manager, identify appropriate functions for the nurse manager to use when addressing this situation: (Select all that apply.)
options: Divide the necessary activities into manageable tasks, so clients adhere to the exercise regimen.
Establish objectives and goals for each area and decide who is accountable for them.
allow clients to organize the activities.
engage in activities that motivate the team and communicate effectively with the responsible staff members.
analyze, appraise, and interpret the performance of responsible staff, and communicate these findings to staff management. F. allow clients to establish objectives and goals.
questions.rationale: Drucker‘s five basic functions include division of work into tasks, development and communication of goals and outcomes, motivation and communication, and analysis, approval, and interpretation of staff performance.

questions.stem: Recruiting among the emerging workforce (18 to 35 year olds) is a challenge for healthcare agencies. Marketing brochures should address the leadership and vision of the healthcare agency. Which of the following workplace environments will attract applicants in the emerging workforce?
options: An environment highlighted by lots of meetings, so staff members can have lots of input
A totally online environment, so staff members will not have to interface with uncaring colleagues
questions.rationale: A study of student nurses who represent this age group indicates that they want a leader who is receptive, approachable, a team player, and motivating.

questions.stem: The nurse manager, as the leader of the unit‘s customer (client) first initiative, has asked the staff nurses to develop and administer a survey to every client before discharge. In asking the staff nurses to accomplish this task, the nurse manager is demonstrating:
options: independence in the nursing manager‘s role.
questions.rationale: Healthy work environments are facilitated by involving staff and others in decision making; gaining access to information is one characteristic of shared decision making. Shared decision-making enables staff to feel valued in policy development and in directing and leading.

questions.stem: A nurse manager is experiencing considerable conflict among staff members because of weekend staffing coverage. During a called staff meeting, the nurse manager asks the disgruntled staff to meet as a group and determine the best staffing practices. In doing this, the nurse manager is using the concept of collaboration to:
options: Focus all energies of staff members on the best possible strategy.
defuse the possibility that staff members will escalate their discontent when staffing the unit on weekends.
questions.rationale: When collaboration is used to solve a conflict or to create new directions, the energies of all parties are focused on solving the problem, versus defeating the opposing party and creating the best possible direction, versus an okay direction. When groups come together and mutual expectations are discussed and fostered, communication and collaboration are enhanced, which results in a more structurally empowered workforce.

questions.stem: A nurse manager‘s responsibility for financial management involves making budgetary decisions. Budgets that allow the nurse manager to allocate resources at the unit level allow:
options: budgetary allocations at the executive nurse level.
budgetary decision making at the point-of-service (POS).
questions.rationale: In organizational structures where decision making occurs at the POS, nurse managers are given some self-control, which includes preparing and implementing a budget that meets the long- and short-term needs of their unit without requiring hierarchical approval.   222

questions.stem: The hospital administrator approves a case management position for a new rehabilitation unit to help reduce costs. In developing the job description, the nurse manager understands that a key element of case management is:
options: managing of care by nurse managers.
coordination of resources for effective outcomes.
rapid discharge of clients to decrease costs.
managing of care for outpatient clients only.
questions.rationale: The key to effective case management is proactive coordination of care from the point of admission to accomplish appropriate and effective outcomes. Case management involves components such as case selection, multidisciplinary assessment, collective planning, coordination of events, negotiation, and evaluation and documentation of the outcomes of patient status in measures of cost. Case management is employed in a variety of settings.

questions.stem: In planning a new wing, the nurse manager complies with the workplace safety requirements of the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA). Which of the following groups is considered to be at high risk for violence in the workplace?
questions.rationale: Nurse managers have responsibility for both patient and staff safety. High-risk areas, such as the Emergency Department, require special attention.

questions.stem: While interviewing for a nurse manager position, Ann is asked to give an example of a situation in which she demonstrated leadership. Which of the following examples exemplifies leadership?
options: Through research and investigation of best practice and practice-based evidence, she proposed a change in the management of incontinence in older adult patients.
She ensures that new policies related to parenteral infusions are implemented consistently within her team.
When asked by her students about institutional policies, she readily and patiently interprets policies to facilitate quality care.
She organizes the team and delegates responsibilities effectively in providing nursing care.
questions.rationale: Nurse managers are responsible for making day-to-day decisions for their units and interpreting established policies, procedures, and mandates. They meet their goals by organizing, staffing, controlling, and solving problems. By contrast, leaders develop a vision and translate that direction into action.

questions.stem: Budgeting and protection of revenues is a function of:
questions.rationale: Managers address complex issues such as planning, budgeting, and allocating resources, whereas leaders address change.

questions.stem: As a nurse manager on a urology unit, you note that there has been a marked increase in medication errors on the unit. Which of the following actions would be consistent with the National Database of Nursing Quality Indicators (NDNQI) measures?
options: Staff are consulted regarding improvements in interprofessional approaches to patient care.
Nursing staff are asked for input regarding the purchase of new medication carts.
A recognition program is developed to acknowledge nurses who have provided safe and exemplary care utilizing skills in the staffing mix to optimize the delivery of patient care.
Recent changes in staffing mixes are examined to determine if the timing of changes coincides with the increase in errors.
questions.rationale: The NDNQI measures are specifically concerned with patient safety and aspects of quality of care that may be affected by changes in the delivery of care or staffing resources. The quality indicators address staff mix and nursing hours for acute-care settings, as well as other care components. The NDNQI project is designed to assist healthcare organizations in identifying links between nursing care and patient outcomes.

questions.stem: A nurse manager in a hospital is deeply concerned that senior administration makes decisions about budgetary directions that affect staffing and other resources without sharing the rationale for changes or demonstrating concern as to how these changes may affect patients or staff. She says she does not feel respected and is emotionally tired as a result. This situation represents:
options: lack of engagement by the administration.
questions.rationale: Organizational culture refers to the basic assumptions and values of an organization, and whether they contribute to relationships and decision-making that are marked by empowerment, information sharing, and truthfulness. Positive work cultures contribute to a perception of being respected in the work environment. Collaborative organizational cultures are essential for nurse managers to proactively work in today‘s complex healthcare environment in a manner that engages them in their work. Interpersonal relationships can be fostered with organizational designs that foster a culture of collaboration, reward and recognition, communication, and a mentoring environment. This demonstrates a lack of engagement by the administration.

questions.stem: As the clinical director of 24 employees, you have been asked to explain to staff members why they are not getting a raise this year, even though they have been working short-handed for many months and patient satisfaction scores have never been higher. Because you believe yourself to be a transformational leader, you will approach this problem by:
options: telling the assistant clinical director and asking her to share the bad news with the other staff members.
posting a note on the bulletin board that includes the phone number of the chief nursing officer, so anyone who has complaints may express them.
showing staff members the budget and asking for input about how to cut costs so that raises will be possible in the future.
meeting with a small group of seasoned staff members and asking them how to break the news.
questions.rationale: Transformational leadership involves engaging those being led and inspiring shared vision in moving toward a goal that all will accept as desirable. This involves enabling and empowering others to believe that their input and effort will make a difference in solving problems.

questions.stem: Nurses on Unit 17 complain that their manager frequently checks up on them and encourages little involvement in decision making, and yet, during performance reviews, praises them for their outstanding performance. Nurses on Unit 18 indicate that their experience is different from that of nurses on Unit 17. The manager on Unit 18 encourages active involvement in decision-making and provides authentic, growth-promoting feedback. The practices on Units 17 and 18 reflect.
options: differences in the managers‘ expectations of their role.
shaping of the workplace behavior of employees.
different approaches to cooperation and collaboration.
questions.rationale: Management theory addresses how managers address employees‘ concerns and needs and the interactions of managers with employees. Expectations of the managerial role affect expectations of self as the manager and of others. McGregor‘s (1960) Theory X and Theory Y made two basic opposing assumptions about employees and how the manager should interact with them. Theory X suggests that people do not like their work and that lower-order needs are more important. Theory Y adopts an optimistic view in which people are seen as capable of self-direction and autonomy.

questions.stem: John is interested in leadership positions within his nursing organization. Although he has been in the same unit for 10 years, he has attended two workshops during that time and has steadfastly refused opportunities to engage in leadership development opportunities or other learning offered as part of the hospital‘s succession planning strategy. He says that he is interested in a leadership role primarily because it will give him a more stable work schedule and will enable him to spend more time with his family. In coaching John, it would be important to:
options: Affirm that his years of service and stability on the unit are the most important attributes for assumption of a leadership role.
Reinforce that his concern with maintaining balance outside work would be a key factor in selecting him for a leadership position.
encourage him to consider the financial rewards of the position, as well as the positive effect on his work schedule.
encourage him to seek out new experiences and learning that will complement his existing strengths derived from experience and his interest in work-life balance.
questions.rationale: According to Covey, effective leaders continually engage in learning and self-renewal, as well as in maintaining a balanced life, radiating positive energy, believing in other people, being concerned with the common good, and being synergistic.

questions.stem: The new head nurse on G Unit has been the subject of a great deal of discussion and complaining during breaks. She is a competent nurse of tremendous integrity with approximately 30 years‘ experience. Her predominant method of problem-solving and communication is through meetings, which can go over the allotted time. The staff may:
options: is represented by a high number of Baby Boomers.
be presenting different generational values and attitudes than the head nurse.
be unresponsive to her transactional leadership style.
wants a leader rather than a manager.
questions.rationale: Leaders who come out of the Baby Boomer generation may be more comfortable with collective action than followers who come out of the Emerging Workforce generation, who are more comfortable with interactions if they are seen as having value for them and with activities if they are seen as having benefit. A group that is highly weighted toward the Emerging workforce generation may find the approach of a leader who is part of the Baby Boomer generation frustrating and may not understand the meaning or value of the meetings.

questions.stem: Kari, a head nurse on the dialysis unit, has been informed during budget planning meetings that budget cuts are likely. She discusses this at the next unit meeting and tells staff members that unless they do their jobs well, their positions may be terminated, and there will be no replacement. Kari is enacting which management style?
questions.rationale: Transactional leaders tend to rely on position and power, and they tend to reward and punish according to performance and conformity with expectations.

questions.stem: The nurse manager plays a unique role in institutional management in that the nurse manager:
options: interprets healthcare trends and their impact on revenues.
questions.rationale: Encouragement of shared decision making, coordination of resources, and interface between internal and external factors, and a unit are all associated with effective management, but could be performed by a manager from any discipline. The nurse manager‘s unique role is modeling professional behavior.

questions.stem: In developing an orientation program, the hospital educator breaks essential organizational information down into chunks, which she develops as online modules. This is an application of which of Drucker‘s functions of management?
options: Organization of activities into manageable tasks
questions.rationale: Organizing the information into online modules is an application of Drucker‘s organizational analysis and the division of activities, decisions, and relations into manageable tasks.

questions.stem: Nancy is a staff nurse who works on a rehabilitation unit. Nancy tells you that the assistants are experiencing difficulty with the new lift and wonders what your thoughts are on organizing an in-service training. Nancy is exhibiting which trait of a follower?
options: Provides a vision for safety that is communicated.
Thrives on taking risks in identifying the problem with safety.
Coordinates the development of knowledge and skills necessary to use the lift.
Assumes responsibility for identifying a safety concern and concedes authority for the solution to you.
questions.rationale: Communication of a vision and risk-taking are leader traits, whereas coordination is associated with manager traits. Taking responsibility while conceding authority to the leader is characteristic of followers.

questions.stem: A competent adult refuses a recommended medication before discharge, stating, “I don’t want that med.” What is the nurse’s best initial action under the ANA Code of Ethics?
options: Administer the medication because it is in the patient’s best interest
Ask the provider to discharge the patient AMA
Explore the patient’s goals and provide information to support informed self-determination
Document refusal and move on without further discussion
questions.rationale: Provision 1 emphasizes respect for human dignity and the patient's right to self-determination; clarify values and support informed choice.

questions.stem: You observe a colleague bypassing barcode scanning. Which ANA provision most directly obligates you to act?
options: Provision 3: Advocate for rights, health, and safety; promote a culture of safety
Provision 5: Duties to self and professional growth
questions.rationale: Provision 3 requires nurses to protect patients and promote a culture of safety, including responding to unsafe practices.

questions.stem: A nurse smells alcohol on a coworker’s breath and notes slurred speech. What is the most ethical action?
options: Report to a supervisor to protect patients and support intervention for the colleague
Confront privately and drop it if denied
questions.rationale: Provision 3 includes taking action regarding impaired practice to protect patients and obtain help for the colleague.

questions.stem: Which statement best reflects Provision 4 regarding nursing authority and accountability?
options: Accountability rests primarily with the employing institution
Only advanced practice nurses are accountable for clinical decisions
Nurses have authority over nursing practice and are responsible and accountable for their practice
Nurses share accountability equally with delegatees for all tasks
questions.rationale: Provision 4 affirms nurses’ authority over nursing practice and responsibility and accountability, including assignment and delegation.

questions.stem: Which task is MOST appropriate to delegate by an RN to a trained CNA under Florida law and ethical guidance?
options: Assess a new post-op patient and titrate IV opioids
Obtain routine vital signs on a stable patient using an established procedure
Interpret telemetry changes and call the provider
questions.rationale: FL 464.0156 allows delegation of tasks that are routine, follow established steps, have predictable outcomes, and require no ongoing assessment.

questions.stem: Under Florida Statute 464.0156, which statement about delegating medication administration is correct?
options: RNs may delegate IV opioid administration to CNAs if supervised
RNs may not delegate Schedule II–IV controlled substances, except limited insulin devices
RNs may delegate any oral controlled medication if policy permits
Medication administration may never be delegated in home health
questions.rationale: FL 464.0156 prohibits delegation of controlled substances (II–IV) with narrow exceptions for certain prefilled insulin.

questions.stem: Delegating prescription medications to a CNA in a nursing home in Florida requires which condition?
options: Only that the resident is stable
That the CNA meets statute-defined training and competency requirements
Only verbal instructions from the RN at the time of delegation
questions.rationale: Florida law permits limited medication delegation if the CNA meets specific training/competency requirements and setting criteria.

questions.stem: Which activity is explicitly included in Florida’s definition of the practice of professional nursing (s. 464.003)?
options: Diagnosing and treating disease independently without protocols
Supervising and teaching other personnel in the performance of nursing acts
Prescribing Schedule II medications as an RN
questions.rationale: FL 464.003 includes health teaching and supervision/teaching of personnel in nursing acts as part of professional nursing.

questions.stem: Florida law states that a professional nurse is responsible and accountable for decisions based on:
options: The nurse’s educational preparation and experience
questions.rationale: FL 464.003 specifies accountability based on educational preparation and experience.

questions.stem: In Florida, practicing professional nursing without an active license is classified as:
options: A civil infraction with a fine only
A misdemeanor of the first degree
A felony of the third degree
questions.rationale: FL 464.016 identifies unlicensed practice as a third-degree felony.

questions.stem: Using the title “Registered Nurse (RN)” in Florida without holding an RN license is:
options: Permitted if the person is a graduate nurse awaiting results
A misdemeanor of the first degree under title protection
Allowed if working under direct supervision
questions.rationale: FL 464.015 restricts title use; unauthorized use is a first-degree misdemeanor.

questions.stem: Which action is a ground for disciplinary action under FL 464.018?
options: Making or filing a false report or record signed in the nurse’s capacity
Reporting an impaired coworker to the supervisor
questions.rationale: FL 464.018 lists making or filing false records/reports among grounds for discipline.

questions.stem: A nurse knows a colleague is unsafe due to impairment. Under FL 464.018, the nurse should:
options: Refer to an impaired practitioner program (s. 456.076) as an alternative to reporting to the department
questions.rationale: Florida law allows referral to an impaired practitioner program to protect patients while assisting the nurse.

questions.stem: An APRN registered for autonomous practice experiences an adverse incident associated with a nursing intervention that led to a hospital transfer. By when must the report be postmarked?
options: Within 3 days of discovering the incident
Within 15 days of the occurrence (or discovery if not in direct care)
questions.rationale: FL 464.0155 requires reporting within 15 days after occurrence (or discovery if not in direct care).

questions.stem: A nurse is pressured to float to an ICU without recent competency validation. Which ANA provision supports declining until safe orientation occurs?
options: Provision 5: Duties to self, including maintaining competence and a safe work environment
questions.rationale: Provision 5 affirms duties to self, including maintaining competence and expecting a safe work environment.

questions.stem: In discussing a high-risk procedure, the nurse ensures the patient understands risks, benefits, and alternatives and supports the patient’s choice. This MOST aligns with:
options: The right to self-determination and respect for autonomy
questions.rationale: Provision 1 (1.4) emphasizes self-determination; nurses support informed choices consistent with patient values.

questions.stem: Posting a de-identified but unique case on a public forum without authorization most directly conflicts with which obligation?
questions.rationale: Provision 3.1 addresses protecting privacy and confidentiality beyond legal minima; online posts risk re-identification.

questions.stem: After delegating blood glucose checks to a trained UAP, the RN remains accountable for:
options: Nothing once the UAP accepts the task
Only documenting the result if normal
Supervision and evaluation of outcomes, intervening based on assessment
questions.rationale: Provision 4.4: RNs retain accountability for appropriate delegation, supervision, and evaluation of outcomes.

questions.stem: Which scenario best exemplifies a violation under FL 464.017 (sexual misconduct)?
options: Developing a social relationship with a former patient after discharge
Using the nurse–patient relationship to solicit sexual activity outside accepted examination or treatment
questions.rationale: FL 464.017 defines sexual misconduct as leveraging the nurse–patient relationship to induce sexual activity outside accepted care.

questions.stem: Advocating to ensure a non-English-speaking patient receives qualified medical interpretation aligns MOST with:
options: Provision 2: Primary commitment to the patient
Provision 8: Collaboration to protect human rights and reduce disparities
questions.rationale: Provision 8 highlights collaboration to protect human rights and address inequities such as language access.
